About The London International Futures and Options Exchange

In commodity trading world, traders can be classified into two classes: hedgers and speculators. You know
+ A hedger watches the underlying commodity and looks to manage the risk of the changing prices.
+ A speculator tries to predict where a market’s price moves may be going, either up or down, and he will try to position himself to profit from the anticipated movement.

Commodities Futures Investing Methods

Once you care about financials, metals, engergies, softs or grains markets, you will find it to interesting reading the Commodities Futures Investing Methods. We learn and get knowledge to be successful such the competitive markets.

First of all, just get to know more about Speculation vs. Hedging! To traders in floor, the terms are not strange any more, but I know that we are here start from different levels. You may be a newbie. Just have a short view of what are they. You know, there are two kinds of traders and the ones investing in commodity trading are partially the hedgers. He is the one who has a position in a cash market. A person who has an actual interest in the trading prices of a particular commodity.
Many hedgers are farmers growing the actual products, but some of them are also end users of a futures commodity, people with an equal interest in trading prices of goods they will buy at a later date. Talking about these markets, corn futures and wheat futures are good examples of markets where people watch trading prices intently. Let's get to know more how traders are working. A person who needs to buy wheat might use the commodity trading prices to place a trade in the futures market to hedge against an increase in the price of wheat. If the trading prices of wheat go up, the futures markets position would possibly gain in value while partially offsetting the increase in raw material costs on the cash market. How about corn? To hedge against a falling price of corn, a farmer might use corn futures market trades. If he sells corn futures now and the price goes down, his crop would be sold for less. However, he would make money in the commodities future trading prices. It would be also true for a wheat farmer wishing to use the commodity markets trading prices to hedge against falling wheat prices. Trading options on futures contracts carries the same possibility. Nevertheless, the expiration dates are a little different than futures contracts. Some speculators will use futures markets rather than option future trading. So, who are speculators? The larger group of participants in commodities future trading is speculators. This group has existed for almost as long as the market themselves. They are willing to assume the risk of trading prices exposure in the markets to attempt to profit from a temporary or long term change in the trading prices of futures contracts. They have a look at fundamental or technical reasons for the commodity trading prices to change and hope to profit from the change. In exchange for this opportunity, speculators create more buyers and sellers in the futures markets and increase the level of liquidity. This group assumes a huge amount of risk for the chance to profit in commodity trading. Do you know why so? The reason is they neither produce nor purchase the actual commodity, they have to offset their futures positions before the expiration date of the contract.

The chance to profit from the daily future trading prices changes for goods is attractive to some traders. Assess the overall risk and determine if it is right for your portfolio once you want to earn from these markets. Learn all you can about commodities markets and make an educated decision before you trade! Earning from these markets involves a substantial risk of loss and is not suitable for all investors. So, and advice for you is that "Do not trade without a good understanding of the markets!"
